Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemical Aging of Biomass Burning Aerosol by Heterogeneous and Photosensitized Heterogeneous Reactions with Atmospheric Trace Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this laboratory-based project, the chemical transformation of biomass burning aerosol (BBA) particles will be studied. BBA are ubiquitous in the atmosphere, have a source strength of similar magnitude to fossil fuel burning, and can affect the atmosphere on local to global scales. The overall goal of this project is to obtain a comprehensive picture of the BBA life-cycle by: 1) Determination of the heterogeneous oxidation kinetics and reaction products of BBA with atmospheric trace gases; 2) Evaluation of the photochemical stability of biomolecular markers; 3) Measurement of the photosensitized heterogeneous kinetics and reaction products of BBA; and 4) Implementation of the detailed heterogeneous chemistry of BBA into atmospheric models. The heterogeneous oxidation kinetics experiments will be carried out with a chemical ionization mass spectrometer (CIMS) coupled to various flow reactors with samples in the bulk (coated wall) and aerosol phases.

Educational objectives involve undergraduate participation in research, development of new curricula, education of middle and high school students and teachers, and increasing diversity in the atmospheric sciences. Middle and high school students from local school districts, including members of underrepresented groups, will be recruited through Stony Brook University. The students will participate in an atmospheric sciences summer workshop on campus, which will involve classes, experimental demonstrations, computer simulations, and hands-on field experience such as conducting meteorological measurements and collecting aerosol particles with subsequent analysis in the laboratory. Subsequent exposure at conferences sponsored by the Collegiate Science and Technology Entry Program (C-STEP) will strengthen the students' knowledge and understanding. A summer workshop will be also be set up to educate secondary school teachers in atmospheric sciences, air pollution, and climate change. Diversity in atmospheric sciences will be further achieved by mentoring and providing research opportunities to minority and low-income students at the undergraduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biomass burning, such as caused by forest fires, represents a large source of gases and aerosol particles to the atmosphere with emissions similar to those generated by fossil fuel combustion. Biomass burning aerosol (BBA) particles affect the atmosphere on local, regional, and global scale. For these reasons BBAs contribute significantly to the total concentration of particulate matter and thus impact air quality and the radiative budget. These ubiquitous organic dominated particles can reside in the atmosphere for up to 1-2 weeks. During atmospheric transport the BBA particles can interact with reactive trace gases leading to their chemical and physical transformation by so-called heterogeneous reactions. These changes in the particle properties will in turn affect the particles’ impact on air quality, health related issues, and regional and global climate. Therefore, it is imperative to better understand the chemical evolution of BBA particles as a result of heterogeneous chemical reactions.      

This award supported experimental, theoretical, and model investigations of heterogeneous kinetics of typical organic compounds present in BBA particles due to reaction with atmospheric trace gases including ozone (O3), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), nitrate radical (NO3), dinitrogen pentoxide (N2O5), and hydroxyl radical (OH). The development of a custom-built chemical ionization mass spectrometer (CIMS) allowed in situ detection of these reactive trace gas species, a necessity to determine corresponding heterogeneous reaction kinetics. CIMS was coupled to different flow reactors in which BBA surrogate compounds or surrogate BBA particles were exposed to the reactive trace gases. This allowed determination of the heterogeneous reaction efficiency. An example of the experimental setup is shown in the attached image and includes the CIMS, an aerosol flow reactor (AFR) equipped with a Beenakker microwave cavity to produce OH, and an irradiated rectangular channel flow reactor (RCFR). The RCFR was employed to investigate the effect of photo-active substances on the heterogeneous reaction kinetics. Gaseous reaction products from the reaction with OH and organic substrates were determined as well using a proton-transfer time-of-flight mass spectrometer as shown in the second image. The significance of these gaseous reaction products is that they can lead to new secondary condensed phase material thereby affecting the atmospheric composition.

We found that O3, NO3, and OH can effectively react with and degrade BBA compounds with significant implications for aerosol source apportionment studies, air quality, and climate. The presence of photo-active substances enhances the reactivity between O3 and BBA compounds and thus has to be considered to better describe the chemical evolution of biomass burning plumes. We observed that the particle phase, i.e. the particle being e.g. liquid or solid, significantly affects the heterogeneous reaction efficiency. The newly determined reaction kinetics from this project have been applied to atmospheric chemistry models that consider the heterogeneous chemical kinetics on a molecular level previously unachieved. These updated models now allow assessment of the most important underlying mechanisms resulting in the chemical transformation of particles in urban environments with poor air quality. Theoretical modeling of the underlying molecular processes allowed us to gain an improved understanding of the heterogeneous kinetic mechanisms.
